title: Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. The rank of an elliptic curve equals the order of vanishing of its L-function at s=1.

meta.author: Birch & Swinnerton-Dyer (1965)
originalContributions: Formal statement of BSD conjecture (weak and strong forms)
Definition of L-functions for elliptic curves

overview.historicalContext: The BSD conjecture arose from extensive computational experiments in the 1960s. It connects arithmetic (rational points) with analysis (L-functions) in a precise quantitative way.
overview.problemStatement:
**Weak BSD:** rank(E(Q)) = ord_{s=1} L(E,s)

**Strong BSD:** The leading Taylor coefficient of L(E,s) at s=1 equals a precise formula involving periods, regulators, and the Shafarevich-Tate group.
overview.proofStrategy:
This file provides:
1. Abstract definitions of elliptic curves and L-functions
2. The formal BSD statement
3. Known proven cases (rank 0, rank 1)
keyInsights: The conjecture is OPEN - one of the Millennium Prize Problems
Proven for rank 0 and rank 1 by Gross-Zagier and Kolyvagin
Modularity theorem is essential (proven by Wiles et al.)

conclusion.summary: The BSD Conjecture remains open. This formalization provides the mathematical framework and statement, along with the known partial results.
conclusion.implications: BSD is central to arithmetic geometry. A proof would have profound implications for understanding elliptic curves and their rational points.
openQuestions: Is the Shafarevich-Tate group always finite?
Can we extend the rank 0 and 1 results to higher rank?
What is the connection to the Bloch-Kato conjecture?
